comment.author: 33659611@N04
comment._content: Galacia!!! I didn't suppose that Americans know this word. Great photo. Thanks for sharing.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: It's Galicia, not Galacia. Galicia is (in this case) a region in Ukraine and Poland (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galicia_(Eastern_Europe))

comment.author: 33659611@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] In Polish: Galicja; in 1910 eastern part of Austro-Hungarian Empire. There were many nations in one huge country. Please look at this map.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Interesting that Jews are left out of the ethnic group map. They were a pretty large group at the time and dominant in sectors of government and the economy. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Galicia_(Eastern_Europe)

comment.author: 33659611@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/76016463@N00] Yes, of course, Jews lived in Galicja too; in smaller or bigger groups, and in rather closed communities. Hope you know the word 'shtetl'. In Polish: sztetł. After 1918 Jews had their representatives in Polish parliament. There were also assimilated Jewish families. But assimilation was not easy process for them. It's an interesting them. If it's possible please read this page: www.jewishmuseum.org.pl/en/cms/home-page/

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content:
Thanks, I will.  That link I posted above doesn't seem to work, and is cutting off the end of the address.  Here's the address by itself,
